guide.title: Gentoo Linux Guide to setting up a User Mode SELinux Environment
guide.abstract: This guide shows you how to set up a User-Mode Linux (UML) installation of SELinux.

body.p: The purpose of this guide is to provide a step by step walk-through for setting up a user-mode linux installation with SELinux support. It provides instructions, pointers, hints and warnings of possible pitfalls. After completing the guide, you will have a fully functional SELinux system running in a user mode linux "jail".

section.title: What you will not find in this document

body.p: This guide is not a replacement for the documentation provided by the UML and SELinux projects. We highly recommend to take a look through the appropriate docs to acquire a full understanding of what the listed commands actually do and to fully understand the decisions you make while setting up the virtual environment.
This guide is not a tutorial on how to use or administer a SELinux-based system.

As the User-Mode Linux website states, user-mode linux (from now onwards abbreviated as UML) allows to "run Linux inside itself". Specifically, user-mode linux provides a virtual machine on which a user can "[r]un buggy software, experiment with new Linux kernels or distributions, and poke around in the internals of Linux, all without risking your main Linux setup." Such a setup is perfect for playing with, testing and familiarizing oneself with SELinux.
The Gentoo Hardened SELinux Subproject describes SELinux as a mandatory access control system using type enforcement and role-based access controls.
Start by getting the user-mode sources and configure the kernel accordingly:

pre.caption: Installation, Configuration and Compilation of the Kernel

body.pre: # emerge sys-kernel/usermode-sources # cd /usr/src/linux-<version>-uml # make menuconfig ARCH=um # make linux ARCH=um # cp linux /usr/local/bin/linux
body.warn: The ARCH=um fragment is extremely important. You have been warned.
body.p: During the configuration of the kernel, be sure to activate the following features:
body.pre:
(Under "Code maturity level options") [*] Prompt for development and/or incomplete code/drivers
(Under "File Systems") [*] Second extended fs support [*] Ext2 extended attributes [ ] Ext2 POSIX Access Control Lists [*] Ext2 Security Labels (If you want ext3) [*] Ext3 journalling file system support [*] Ext3 extended attributes [ ] Ext3 POSIX Access Control Lists [*] Ext3 Security Labels
(Under "File Systems --> Pseudo filesystems") [ ] /dev file system support (OBSOLETE) [ ] Automatically mount at boot [*] /dev/pts file system for Unix98 PTYs [*] /dev/pts Extended Attributes [*] /dev/pts Security Labels [*] Virtual memory file system support (former shm fs)
(Under "Security Options") [*] Enable different security models <*> Capabilities Support [*] NSA SELinux Support [*] NSA SELinux Development Support
body.warn: ReiserFS and JFS are not supported in SELinux
body.p: No other policy should be added.
Now continue with installing the UML utilities.

The root_fs file needed for user-mode linux is a single file that contains an entire Gentoo Linux filesystem. To generate this file you will need to have Loopback device support enabled in the host (non-user-mode) kernel.

Generating the root_fs file itself will be our last step. First we will generate a Gentoo filesystem in an ordinary chroot. Download (or extract) a stage tarball and start the Gentoo installation as you would do with a live system.
There are a few quirks that you need to take into consideration:

ul.li: You can safely ignore warnings about the SELinux module not being loaded; the warnings should go away once the SELinux kernel is used
Edit /etc/make.profile/packages and remove the "*" in front of the virtual/bootloader line if it exists
Of all available system loggers, only syslog-ng and metalogd have been sufficiently tested with SELinux
The only cron daemon that seems to work with SELinux is vixie-cron

body.p: When you edit /etc/fstab you'll need to make a couple of changes:

ul.li: /dev/ubd/0 should have an fs type of ext2 or ext3

body.p: Also add the following two lines:
body.pre: none /dev/pts devpts gid=5,mode=620 0 0 none /selinux selinuxfs defaults 0 0
body.p: Let's create the devices we referenced in fstab:
body.pre: # for i in `seq 0 7`; do mknod /dev/ubd$i b 98 $(($i*16)); done
body.p: Now build the SELinux policies:
Now finish up the installation and proceed with creating the root_fs file.

When we check the size of the chroot environment we find out that it takes a hefty 600M to 1.2G (depending on the stage you used). Because of this hefty foot-print, we're going to have to make an image with some room -- let's start with 1.5G.
body.pre: # cd /mnt/gentoo # tar cvjpf ~/root_fs.tbz2 * # cd # dd if=/dev/zero of=root_fs seek=1500 count=1 bs=1M # mke2fs -F root_fs # mount -o loop root_fs /mnt/loop/ # tar xvjpf root_fs.tbz2 -C /mnt/loop # umount /mnt/loop
body.p: Let's also create a 500MB swap file.
body.pre: # dd if=/dev/zero of=swap_fs seek=500 count=1 bs=1M # mkswap -f swap_fs
body.p: Now see if it works:
body.pre: # linux gentoo=nodevfs con0=fd:0,fd:1 con1=xterm con2=xterm con=null ubd0=root_fs ubd1=swap_fs
body.note: User-mode linux uses xterms for the virtual consoles that are run at boot time, so you need to make sure that the terminal from which you run user-mode linux has $DISPLAY properly set (along with proper xhost/xauth permissions).
body.p: The only errors you see on startup should be along the lines of Couldn't get a file descriptor referring to the console from setfont and keymaps. These errors are harmless, but if you want to get rid of them, do the following:
body.pre: # rc-update del keymaps # rc-update del consolefont
body.p: Once we're here, the last thing to do is label the filesystem.
body.pre: (From inside the Gentoo SELinux environment) # cd /etc/security/selinux/src/policy # make relabel # reboot
body.p: Congratulations; you're all set and ready :)
